results.raw_content:
Why LeBron James Is A Much Better Player Than Michael Jordan

Why LeBron James Is A Much Better Player Than Michael Jordan

The debate over basketball’s greatest player of all time has raged for years, with LeBron James and Michael Jordan often at the center. While Jordan’s legacy looms large, a closer look reveals that LeBron James has surpassed him in many key areas.

LeBron James has proven to be a more versatile and well-rounded player than Michael Jordan. He excels not just in scoring but also in playmaking, rebounding, and defensive versatility. His ability to impact the game in multiple ways sets him apart from Jordan’s primarily scoring-focused approach.

LeBron’s longevity and consistency are unmatched in NBA history. He has maintained an elite level of play for nearly two decades, adapting his game as he’s aged and continuing to dominate well into his 30s. This sustained excellence across eras and against evolving competition strengthens his case as the true GOAT of basketball.

Jared Goff’s Wife Christen Harper’s Outfit To Lions Game Goes Viralhttps://t.co/8NbbpmVWBp

— Game 7 (@game7__) December 6, 2024



Early Years and Rise to Stardom

LeBron James and Michael Jordan both emerged as basketball prodigies in their youth. Their paths to stardom, however, took different routes shaped by their unique circumstances and abilities.

LeBron James: The Prodigy from Akron

LeBron James was born on December 30, 1984, in Akron, Ohio. His exceptional talent became evident early on, drawing national attention while still in high school. At St. Vincent-St. Mary High School, James led his team to three state championships.

His scoring and passing abilities were unparalleled for his age. James averaged 31.6 points per game as a senior, securing his position as the top high school player in the nation.

The Cleveland Cavaliers selected James as the first overall pick in the 2003 NBA Draft. He immediately impacted the league, averaging 20.9 points, 5.9 assists, and 5.5 rebounds in his rookie season.

Michael Jordan: Crafting a Legend in Carolina

Michael Jordan was born on February 17, 1963, in Brooklyn, New York. He famously failed to make his high school varsity team as a sophomore, using this setback as motivation to improve.

Jordan’s talent blossomed at the University of North Carolina. He hit the game-winning shot in the 1982 NCAA Championship game as a freshman. Jordan averaged 17.7 points per game over three seasons in college.

The Chicago Bulls drafted Jordan third overall in 1984. He quickly established himself as a prolific scorer, averaging 28.2 points per game in his rookie season. Jordan’s shooting accuracy and athleticism set him apart from his peers.

Dominance on the Court

LeBron James has showcased unparalleled dominance across multiple facets of the game. His blend of scoring prowess, playmaking ability, and defensive impact sets him apart as a more complete player than Michael Jordan.

Scoring Abilities: Titles and Averages

LeBron James has consistently demonstrated elite scoring capabilities throughout his career. While he may not have as many scoring titles as Jordan, James has maintained an impressive career scoring average of 27.2 points per game.

His versatility as a scorer allows him to excel in various situations. James can drive to the basket with power, shoot from mid-range, and knock down three-pointers with accuracy.

In the 2019-2020 season, at age 35, James led the league in assists while still averaging 25.3 points per game. This highlights his ability to maintain high scoring output even as he has evolved his game.

Assist and Playmaking Skills

LeBron James’s playmaking abilities far surpass those of Michael Jordan. James has consistently ranked among the league leaders in assists throughout his career. His court vision and passing skills are exceptional for a player of his size and position.

As of the 2023-2024 season, James has averaged 7.3 assists per game over his career. He has led the league in assists multiple times, showcasing his ability to create opportunities for teammates.

James’s playmaking extends beyond traditional assists. His basketball IQ allows him to make quick decisions and find open teammates in complex offensive sets.

Defense: Steals, Blocks, and All-Defense Accolades

Defensively, LeBron James has proven to be a more versatile and impactful player than Michael Jordan. James’s size and athleticism allow him to guard multiple positions effectively, from point guards to power forwards.

James has been named to the NBA All-Defensive First Team five times. He consistently ranks among the league leaders in steals, averaging 1.6 per game over his career.

His shot-blocking ability adds another dimension to his defensive impact. James has averaged 0.8 blocks per game throughout his career, with many coming as spectacular chase-down blocks in crucial moments.

While Jordan was known for his on-ball defense, James’s ability to defend across positions and impact the game through help defense gives him an edge in overall defensive versatility.

Peak Performance and Athleticism

LeBron James’ exceptional physical abilities and basketball intelligence set him apart from Michael Jordan. James’ unparalleled combination of size, speed, and strength allows him to dominate on both ends of the court.

Physicality and Durability

At 6’9″ and 250 pounds, LeBron James possesses a rare blend of size and agility. His frame allows him to overpower smaller defenders while maintaining the quickness to blow past larger opponents.

James’ durability is remarkable, having played over 1,400 NBA games across 20 seasons. He has avoided major injuries throughout his career, demonstrating exceptional physical resilience.

His vertical leap, measured at 44 inches, rivals that of smaller guards. This explosiveness, combined with his strength, enables James to finish through contact at the rim and be a formidable shot-blocker.

Basketball IQ and Court Vision

James’ mental acuity on the court is unmatched. He processes the game at an elite level, anticipating plays before they develop. His photographic memory allows him to recall specific game situations with incredible detail.

His court vision and passing ability are extraordinary. James averages 7.4 assists per game for his career, showcasing his skill in creating opportunities for teammates.

He excels at reading defenses and making split-second decisions. This ability to analyze and exploit opposing strategies in real-time sets him apart from other players.

Sports Science and Training Regimen

James invests heavily in his body, reportedly spending $1.5 million annually on physical maintenance. His regimen includes cryotherapy, hyperbaric chambers, and personalized nutrition plans.

He employs a team of specialists, including biomechanists and recovery experts, to optimize his performance. This scientific approach to training has contributed to his longevity and consistent high-level play.

James’ dedication to strength training and flexibility work is evident in his physique and on-court performance. He maintains his explosiveness while building the strength necessary to withstand the physical demands of the NBA.

Championships and Finals

LeBron James has achieved remarkable success in the NBA Finals, surpassing Michael Jordan in several key areas. His exceptional performances and longevity have allowed him to accumulate impressive accolades on basketball’s biggest stage.

Finals Appearances and Victories

LeBron James has made 10 NBA Finals appearances, significantly more than Michael Jordan’s 6. This feat demonstrates James’ ability to consistently lead his teams to the championship round across multiple franchises. James has won 4 NBA championships with three different teams: the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers, and Los Angeles Lakers. While Jordan won 6 championships, all with the Chicago Bulls, James’ success with multiple organizations showcases his adaptability and leadership.

James’ Finals appearances span a longer period, from 2007 to 2020, highlighting his sustained excellence and ability to compete at the highest level for over a decade. His championships have come against formidable opponents, including the Golden State Warriors dynasty and the San Antonio Spurs.

Performance in NBA Finals

In the NBA Finals, LeBron James has consistently delivered outstanding individual performances. He has averaged 28.4 points, 10.2 rebounds, and 7.8 assists per game across his Finals appearances. These numbers demonstrate his all-around impact on the game.

James has recorded triple-doubles in the Finals on multiple occasions, showcasing his versatility. His ability to impact the game in various ways, from scoring to facilitating to rebounding, sets him apart from Jordan’s more scoring-focused approach.

Notable performances include his 2016 Finals series against the Warriors, where he led both teams in points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocks – a feat never before accomplished in NBA history.

NBA Finals MVP Awards

LeBron James has won 4 NBA Finals MVP awards, recognizing his crucial role in his teams’ championship victories. He earned this honor with three different franchises: twice with the Miami Heat (2012, 2013), once with the Cleveland Cavaliers (2016), and once with the Los Angeles Lakers (2020).

While Jordan won 6 Finals MVP awards, James’ ability to earn this accolade with multiple teams is unprecedented. It highlights his capacity to elevate different rosters to championship level. James’ Finals MVP performances have included historic achievements, such as leading the greatest comeback in NBA Finals history against the 73-win Warriors in 2016.

His Finals MVP awards span a longer period (2012-2020) compared to Jordan’s (1991-1998), demonstrating James’ sustained excellence at the highest level of competition.

Awards and Recognition

LeBron James has amassed an impressive collection of awards and honors throughout his career, solidifying his status as one of basketball’s all-time greats. His accolades span individual achievements, team success, and international recognition.

Most Valuable Player Awards

LeBron James has secured the NBA Most Valuable Player (MVP) award four times – in 2009, 2010, 2012, and 2013. This places him among an elite group of players with multiple MVP wins.

James has also earned four NBA Finals MVP awards, matching his championship victories. His ability to elevate his game on the biggest stage is a testament to his clutch performances.

All-Star and All-NBA Selections

LeBron’s consistent excellence is reflected in his 19 consecutive All-Star selections, a streak that began in his second NBA season. This remarkable run demonstrates his enduring impact and popularity.

James has been named to the All-NBA First Team a record 13 times. He has also earned three All-NBA Second Team selections, bringing his total All-NBA honors to 16.

His defensive prowess is evident in his five All-Defensive First Team and one All-Defensive Second Team selections.

Other Honors and Accolades

James’ trophy case includes numerous other accolades. He was named the NBA Rookie of the Year in 2004, setting the stage for his illustrious career.

On the international stage, LeBron has captured two Olympic gold medals (2008, 2012) and a bronze (2004) representing the United States.

James has led the league in scoring once (2008) and in assists once (2020), showcasing his versatility. He’s also received the J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award for his off-court contributions.

Global Influence and Cultural Impact

LeBron James has transcended basketball to become a global icon and cultural influencer. His impact extends far beyond the court, shaping business, society, and popular culture in unprecedented ways.

Beyond the Court: Business and Social Influence

LeBron’s business acumen has set new standards for athlete entrepreneurship. He’s built a media empire, including SpringHill Entertainment and Uninterrupted, producing content that amplifies diverse voices.

His shrewd investments, like a stake in Liverpool FC, have multiplied his wealth and influence. James has leveraged his platform for social change, opening the I Promise School in Akron and advocating for racial justice.

His Value Over Replacement extends to his off-court endeavors, creating opportunities and inspiring millions worldwide.

The Cultural Phenomenon of ‘The Last Dance’

While ‘The Last Dance’ documentary revitalized interest in Michael Jordan’s legacy, it also sparked renewed comparisons to LeBron. The series highlighted Jordan’s cultural impact in the 90s, but LeBron’s influence spans a more globally connected era.

James has excelled in the social media age, engaging fans directly and shaping narratives. His Olympic performances with Team USA have showcased his skills on an international stage, cementing his status as a global ambassador for basketball.

LeBron’s career, like the documentary, has become a cultural touchstone, redefining the concept of GOAT in a modern context.

Comparable Greats and Competition

LeBron James has faced formidable opponents and comparisons throughout his career. His achievements stand out against both contemporary rivals and NBA legends of the past.

Comparisons with Other NBA Legends

LeBron’s versatility and longevity set him apart from many greats. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the all-time leading scorer, is often mentioned alongside James. LeBron surpassed Kareem’s scoring record while maintaining higher assist numbers, showcasing his dual threat as a scorer and playmaker.

James’ all-around game draws parallels to Magic Johnson, though LeBron’s scoring prowess exceeds Magic’s. His defensive capabilities, evidenced by multiple All-Defensive Team selections, rival those of elite two-way players like Scottie Pippen.

Phil Jackson, who coached Jordan, has praised LeBron’s basketball IQ and leadership skills. These qualities have allowed James to elevate teammates like Draymond Green to championship levels.

Difficulties and Triumphs Over Rival Teams

LeBron’s path to success has been marked by intense rivalries. The Detroit Pistons challenged him early in his career, much like they did with Jordan. James overcame this hurdle, leading his team past Detroit in the 2007 Eastern Conference Finals.

His battles with the Boston Celtics’ “Big Three” and the San Antonio Spurs defined his early Finals appearances. James faced these veteran-laden teams multiple times, learning and adapting with each encounter.

The Golden State Warriors dynasty presented perhaps his toughest challenge. Despite their historic regular-season success, LeBron led his team to victory against them in 2016, overcoming a 3-1 deficit in the Finals.

Leveraging Statistics and Record Books

LeBron James’ statistical achievements surpass Michael Jordan’s in several key areas. The numbers paint a clear picture of James’ superior all-around impact and longevity in the NBA.

Analyzing Career Averages and Statistical Milestones

LeBron James has maintained remarkable career averages across multiple categories. He averages 27.1 points, 7.5 rebounds, and 7.4 assists per game. James ranks higher than Jordan in career rebounds and assists.

James became the all-time leading scorer in NBA history in 2023, surpassing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s long-standing record. He has also amassed over 10,000 assists and 10,000 rebounds.

James has made 10 NBA Finals appearances compared to Jordan’s 6. He has won championships with 3 different franchises: the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers, and Los Angeles Lakers.

Triple-Doubles, Rebounds, and Impact on the Game

LeBron James ranks 5th all-time in triple-doubles with 105, far exceeding Jordan’s 28. This demonstrates James’ superior versatility and ability to impact games in multiple ways.

James averages more rebounds per game than Jordan (7.5 vs 6.2). His rebounding prowess, especially on the defensive end, has been crucial to his teams’ success.

James’ passing ability sets him apart. He averages 7.4 assists per game compared to Jordan’s 5.3. This playmaking skill allows James to elevate his teammates’ performance.

James has evolved his game over time, adapting to different roles and offensive systems. His versatility and basketball IQ have allowed him to maintain elite production well into his 30s.

Conclusion and Legacy

LeBron James has cemented his place as the superior basketball player compared to Michael Jordan.

His on-court performances and statistical achievements speak volumes about his greatness.

James’ versatility sets him apart. He excels in scoring, playmaking, and defense – a true all-around player.

His ability to impact the game in multiple ways gives him an edge over Jordan’s primarily scoring-focused approach.

Longevity is another key factor. LeBron has maintained an elite level of play for two decades, surpassing Jordan’s career length.

This sustained excellence allows James to accumulate more impressive career totals.

James’ basketball IQ and court vision are unparalleled. He reads the game exceptionally well, making smart decisions that benefit his team.

While this sometimes leads to turnovers, it’s a small price for his overall positive impact.

The evolution of the game must be considered when comparing eras. LeBron has thrived in a more competitive, globally-influenced NBA.

His adaptability to changing playing styles further solidifies his legacy.

A longtime sports reporter, Carlos Garcia has written about some of the biggest and most notable athletic events of the last 5 years. He has been credentialed to cover MLS, NBA and MLB games all over the United States. His work has been published on Fox Sports, Bleacher Report, AOL and the Washington Post.

Share this:

Carlos Garcia

results.raw_content:
LeBron James: Analyzing What Makes Him the Most Versatile Player in NBA History

Now that LeBron James can add the title "NBA champion" to his resume, it's time to examine where James fits among the NBA's all-time greats.

It wasn't that long ago that James was making noise (and history) in the Ohio High School Athletic Association. When James was just 16 years old, Ryan Jones of Slam Magazine said the then-sophomore might be "the best high school basketball player in America."

Grant Wahl of Sports Illustrated noted the high level of praise NBA scouts doled on James as a high-school junior who already impressed with his all-around game.

Heaping that much praise on a high schooler often can be disastrous.

And James' admirers had set the bar higher than that for any high-school player before or since.

Dubbed "King James," he was also dubbed Jordan's heir apparent before he had even left the campus of St. Vincent-St. Mary High School in Akron, Ohio.

There was no way that this child (not even a 6'7", 225-pound man-child) could ever live up to this level of buzz, right?

Well, not exactly...

Fast forward to 2012, and James is now unquestionably the best player on the planet. Basketball minds are still raving about his versatility, and those Jordan comparisons still resonate.

Yet it's hard to say that James has lived up to the "next Jordan" moniker.

He's simply the first LeBron James.

Truth be told, James has drawn more comparisons to Magic Johnson than Jordan, but even those fail to capture the immense talent of the King.

The Johnson-James comparisons draw from a reasonable origin: Both players are 6'8" or taller with the handles, court vision and decision-making to play the point-guard position.

But as great as Johnson was, he was never the scorer nor the defender that James is.

Johnson topped the 20-point mark just four seasons in his career (his best scoring year came when he averaged 23.9 in 1986-87), while James has topped it in each of his nine seasons and has even topped the 30-point plateau in two different seasons.

As for the defensive comparisons, Johnson was lauded as a smart team defender. But he never made an all-defensive team in his NBA career.

James, meanwhile, has appeared on the past four all-defensive first teams and realistically should have an NBA Defensive Player of the Year Award by now (the only piece of NBA hardware still evading the 27-year-old).

Wait, James can score and defend? Maybe those Jordan comparisons aren't too off base.

In terms of raw talent and importance to their teams, the comparisons are warranted.

But the two played vastly different games.

Jordan was every bit the athletic specimen then that James is today, but he was not initiating former Bulls coach Phil Jackson's offense. Jordan has the edge in career scoring (30.1 to 27.6), while James has the advantage in assists (6.9 to 5.3).

Likewise, while Jordan could defend anyone on the perimeter, he simply didn't have the size to defend the bigs of his era on a nightly basis.

James is simply unlike anyone player the game has seen.

With his combination of size, strength, intelligence and athleticism, he can do everything on the basketball court.

Sports fans love to compare players across eras in order to "decide" who was the greatest or who will be the next so-and-so.

But basketball fans would be much better with that sliver of hope in searching for the next Jordan. Because there will never be another King James.

results.content: I thought itâd be interesting to look back at the teams Jordan beat in his six trips to the Finals against the four teams LeBron has faced in the Finals so far. 1993: Bulls 4, Phoenix 2 â Iâd listen to an argument that all of LeBronâs Finals opponents were better than this Suns team. 1997: Bulls 4, Utah 2 â Might be the best team Jordan beat in the Finals. Hereâs how Iâd rank the teams Jordan beat in the Finals: 1) 91 Lakers, 2) 97 Jazz, 3) 98 Jazz, 4) 93 Suns, 5) 96 Sonics, 6) 92 Blazers. Hereâs how Iâd rank the 10 opponents Jordan and LeBron have faced in the Finals:
results.raw_content:
Michael Jordan vs. LeBron: Who Faced Tougher Competition in the NBA Finals?

By Jason McIntyre | Jun 26, 2013

Michael Jordan vs. LeBron James.

Michael Jordan finished his brilliant NBA career with six championships. LeBron James â only 28 â has won two titles. Nate Silver of the Times had a great breakdown of where they both were at 28, and what LeBronâs chances are of catching Jordanâs six rings. (Spoiler: 30 percent). Also, hereâs a graphic that was making the rounds on the internet over the weekend that you may be interested in:

Undeniable: LeBron has accomplished more at this stage in his NBA career than Jordan has. [Counter: But Jordan went to college!]

I wanted to take a slightly different angle. The 80âs belonged to Magic and Larry. Magicâs last game in his prime was in 1991 (letâs not count that brief run in 1996), and Birdâs was in 1992 at the age of 35. Then, Michael Jordan took over. Many a basketball argument has boiled down to, âhey, Jordan was beating up on a watered-down league compared to the 80s â there were far fewer legendary stars.â [Counter: Huh? The 80s were all Lakers/Celtics with a smattering of Dr. J, Moses and the Pistons.]

I thought itâd be interesting to look back at the teams Jordan beat in his six trips to the Finals against the four teams LeBron has faced in the Finals so far.

1991: Bulls 4, LA Lakers 1 â Lakers won Game 1, Bulls owned rest of the series. Scott & Worthy were hurt and missed Game 5. Scott took just 18 shots in the series.
1992: Bulls 4, Portland 2 â Probably the weakest team the Bulls beat in Jordanâs six trips to the Finals. Won 57 games. Drexler in his prime.
1993: Bulls 4, Phoenix 2 â Iâd listen to an argument that all of LeBronâs Finals opponents were better than this Suns team. Won 62 games. Barkley was the NBA MVP.

1996: Bulls 4, Seattle 2 â A good Sonics team, and Kemp had a beastly series, but heâs not Dirk, thatâs for sure. Won 64 games.
1997: Bulls 4, Utah 2 â Might be the best team Jordan beat in the Finals. Karl Malone was the League MVP. Won 64 games.
1998: Bulls 4, Utah 2 â Virtually the exact same core as the year prior. Won 62 games.

Hereâs how Iâd rank the teams Jordan beat in the Finals: 1) 91 Lakers, 2) 97 Jazz, 3) 98 Jazz, 4) 93 Suns, 5) 96 Sonics, 6) 92 Blazers.

LeBronâs Final opponents? This is probably due to recency bias, but Iâd say theyâve been considerably tougher than the teams Jordan beat:

2007: Spurs 4, Cavaliers 0 â The Spurs went 16-4 in the playoffs. Tim Duncan is a Top 10 player in NBA history and better than any of the players Jordan beat, with the exception of Magic. [Counter: 1991 Magic led the NBA in turnovers, his shooting from the field was in steady decline, he was only 2nd in the NBA in assists, and the Lakers were at the end of their dynasty, finishing 2nd in the West.] Tony Parker was the MVP of this series, and just for fun â¦ in the annals of NBA history, who will wind up thought of as the better player, Tony Parker or Gary Payton? Tony Parker or John Stockton?

2011: Mavericks 4, Heat 2 â Dirk Nowitzki is considered one of the best shooting forwards in NBA history. Barkley or Dirk? Barkley was 29 on his only trip to the Finals, and averaged 27 points and 13 rebounds in that series. He had 32-12-10 in a Game 4 loss, and 42-13 in a Game 2 loss. Dirk or Kemp? Dirk or Mailman? Dirk averaged 26-9 in the 2011 Finals, and made 45 of 46 free throws. Fun discussion where thereâs no right or wrong answer: Was Dirk a more complete player than Barkley, Kemp and Mailman? The Mavs beat Kobe, Durant and LeBron in the postseason.

2012: Heat 4, Thunder 1 â Difficult to say how good this Thunder team was. We may not know for a few years. But at this rate, Durant and Westbrook (assuming they stick together) could end up having Hall of Fame careers and being similar to Stockton/Malone, who went to the Finals twice. Jordan never faced a dominant young scoring tandem such as Durant and Westbrook in the Finals.

2013: Heat 4, Spurs 3: Duncan at 37, Ginobili at 35. And San Antonio benefited from the Westbrook injury (and swept the Lakers minus Kobe). The West was such a mess, the Spurs struggled against the Warriors (4-2), then swept the Grizzlies, who were only there because of the Westbrook injury. Iâd compare these Spurs tot he 1991 Lakers, but that Laker team was injured and not nearly as old. Comparing across decades is impossible and an exercise in futility, but wouldnât this yearâs Spurs team have beaten any of Jordanâs Finals opponents?

Hereâs how Iâd rank the 10 opponents Jordan and LeBron have faced in the Finals:

1. 2007 Spurs (LeBron)
2. 1991 Lakers (Jordan)
3. 2011 Mavericks (LeBron)
4. 1997 Jazz (Jordan)
5. 1998 Jazz (Jordan)
6. 2013 Spurs (LeBron)
7. 2012 Thunder (LeBron)
8. 1993 Suns (Jordan)
9. 1996 Sonics (Jordan)
10. 1992 Blazers (Jordan)

results.raw_content:
Comparing Michael Jordan & LeBron James’s Finals All-Star Opponents

When people ask about the Michael Jordan vs LeBron James debate, one of the pro-Michael Jordan arguments revolves around his 6-0 Finals record.

What the younger generation may not know or remember, is exactly who Michael Jordan faced in the Finals.

This is a side by side comparison of the All-Stars that Michael Jordan has faced vs the All-Stars LeBron James has faced.

Who do you think had tougher Finals competition?

Michael Jordan

1991: Magic Johnson and James Worthy.
1992: Clyde Drexler
1993: Charles Barkley, Dan Majerle.
1996: Gary Payton, Shawn Kemp
1997: John Stockton, Karl Malone,
1998: Karl Malone

LeBron James

2007: Tim Duncan, Tony Parker,
2011: Dirk Nowitzki
2012: Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook
2013: Tim Duncan, Tony Parker
2014: Tony Parker
2015: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson
2016: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, Draymond Green
2017: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, Draymond Green, Kevin Durant.

Whilst it’s clear LeBron had a quite a full plate when it comes to amount of All-Stars, who’s were better? Could you make the argument that while LeBron is currently 3-4 he’s had a tougher run? Or were Michael Jordan’s All-Time OG opponents more of a handful?

If you take those Bulls teams and instead compare them to the average opponent faced by LeBron James, they would have entered the Finals with an ELO rating of just 20 points higher.

The Last Dance: Did Michael Jordan or LeBron James face tougher competition in the playoffs?
MICAH ADAMS
•
The final two episodes of "The Last Dance" air this weekend and will feature a look back at Michael Jordan's triumph over the Utah Jazz in the 1998 Finals.
When we took a closer look into all 37 of Jordan's playoff opponents, we found that the 1998 Jazz team was not only the best team that those Bulls faced off against in the NBA Finals, but also the best team that Jordan ever beat in the playoffs. That's according to FiveThirtyEight's Complete History of the NBA which includes power ratings for every team after every single game in NBA history.
MORE: Ranking all 37 of Jordan's playoff opponents
Of course, these days nary a second goes by after uttering Jordan's name before the words "LeBron James" crashes the party.
The GOAT debate between the two legends has raged on for years and recently re-surfaced with the 10-episode arc chronicling Jordan's rise to power throughout the 1990s. As if that fire needed more fuel, ESPN released its updated list of top players of all-time earlier this week with Jordan claiming the top spot just ahead of James.
Honestly, it's a debate that has no right or wrong answer so we're not going to bother getting into it right now.
What we are here to do, however, is shed some light on the teams both legends beat en route to their place atop the NBA's Mt. Rushmore. In poring through all of Jordan's playoff opponents, I couldn't help but wonder how his road to six championships compares with LeBron's. While King James can't match Jordan's ring total, he holds a 9-6 edge in Finals appearances which shoud count for something. 
Is LeBron's count of Finals appearances inflated due to a weakened Eastern Conference? Or does his playoff record stack up favourably to Jordan?
For the purposes of this discussion, we're once again utilizing FiveThirtyEight's all-time team ratings. Curious about how it works? Read more about it here. Rather than bore you with the method beyond the madness, let's dive headfirst into the results sure to drive many mad.
The overall picture
There were 82 playoff opponents to consider in all — 37 for Jordan, 45 for James.
If you simply take the average rating of every team they played, Jordan comes out on top with the harder slate.
MORE: The 76 players with perfect records against MJ
Case closed then, right? That's it, problem solved... thanks for reading!
Not so fast...
There's far more to it than meets the eye.
LeBron's easier path to the Finals
LeBron James has famously never lost in the 1st Round, a perfect 13-0 record.
He didn't just win, he pummels teams. Prior to the grueling seven-game series against the Pacers in 2018, he had won a ridiculous 21 consecutive games in the opening round, essentially never even sweating an early round exit for nearly a decade. The only two players under the current 16-team playoff format (since 1984) that can hold a candle to his early-round dominance are Derek Fisher and Robert Horry, both of whom went 16-0 in the 1st Round.
Unlike Jordan, LeBron never faced a juggernaut early on.
The toughest opponent Jordan ever faced was the 1985-86 Celtics, one of the greatest teams in NBA history who swept Jordan's Bulls despite a stellar showing by the then second-year guard. In addition to that legendary Celtics team that featured five Hall of Famers, Jordan also squared off against a 59-win Milwaukee Bucks team in 1985 that featured the league's best defence spearheaded by two-time Defensive Player of the Year Sidney Moncrief. According to FiveThirtyEight, that Bucks team was better than 34 of the 36 teams that James has played in all rounds leading up to the NBA Finals.
The toughest opponent James has played in the first round was a 2011-12 Knicks team that fired Mike D'Antoni halfway through the season after an 18-24 start. That team starred Carmelo Anthony, a banged up Amar'e Stoudemire and J.R. Smith.
It's not just the first round either.
If you take every team that Jordan and James faced in the East, you'll find that it's Jordan who faced the stiffer competition in rounds leading up to the Finals.
Eight of the toughest 11 opponents belong to Jordan and if you limit it to just the years in which they reached the Finals, six of the top eight were MJ opponents.
It's even more drastic when looking strictly at who each of them faced in the Conference Finals. If you line up all 18 of their Conference Finals opponents, four of the top five were foes of Jordan's Bulls while seven of the bottom eight teams were ones that faced off against LeBron's Cavs or Heat. 
The 1997-98 Pacers team featured in "The Last Dance" that pushed Jordan to seven games ranks higher than eight of the 10 teams LeBron has played in the Conference Finals. The one feather in LeBron's cap is the 2010-11 Bulls who went 62-20 and featured league MVP Derrick Rose. That Bulls team sports a higher ELO rating than any of the teams that Jordan beat in the East, barely edging out the 1993 Knicks.
Hardest Pre-Finals Opponents
Team    Round   Rating  Who?    Result
1986 Celtics    1st Round   1770    MJ  Lost
1989 Pistons    Conf Finals 1767    MJ  Lost
2008 Celtics    Conf Semis  1700    LeBron  Lost
2011 Bulls  Conf Finals 1698    LeBron  Won
1985 Bucks  1st Round   1697    MJ  Lost
1993 Knicks Conf Finals 1696    MJ  Won
1990 Pistons    Conf Finals 1686    MJ  Lost
1998 Pacers Conf Finals 1680    MJ  Won
2009 Magic  Conf Finals 1680    LeBron  Lost
1987 Celtics    1st Round   1676    MJ  Lost
1996 Magic  Conf Finals 1671    MJ  Won
Did LeBron have it easier prior to reaching the Finals? Yes.
But once there... it's an entirely different story.
Finals opponents
The low-hanging fruit is that Jordan never dealt with anyone quite like the Golden State Warriors, a historic juggernaut that just so happened to come along right smack in the middle of LeBron's stranglehold on the East.
Imagine if Jordan's prime ran parallel to Larry Bird's Celtics or Magic Johnson's Lakers? What if instead of catching the tail end of both, he instead ran into them year after year?
There's this tendency to think "Warriors" first and foremost when thinking about LeBron's trips to the Finals and while those teams certainy reign surpreme, they also in a way underscore the relative strength of his other Finals opponents. Back in 2017 I wrote about how LeBron's worst Finals opponent — the 2006-07 San Antonio Spurs — ranked in the 73rd percentile of Finals teams ever. That was before he took on the Warriors for the fourth straight year. 
All nine of LeBron's Finals opponents rank among the top 36 teams ever to reach the NBA Finals, an astounding statement regarding his quality of opposition. 
Even more illuminating is when you factor in how those compare to the teams Michael Jordan squared off against when ammassing that unassailable 6-0 Finals record.
That Spurs team which grades out as the worst of the nine that James played against ranks higher than four of the six teams the Bulls beat, including all three from the first three-peat.
Every Finals Opponent
Team    Rating  Opponent
2017 Warriors   1850    LeBron
2015 Warriors   1802    LeBron
2016 Warriors   1790    LeBron
1998 Jazz   1762    MJ
1997 Jazz   1751    MJ
2012 Thunder    1737    LeBron
2014 Spurs  1730    LeBron
2011 Mavericks  1717    LeBron
2013 Spurs  1711    LeBron
2018 Warriors   1710    LeBron
2007 Spurs  1705    LeBron
1992 Blazers    1702    MJ
1991 Lakers 1697    MJ
1996 Sonics 1695    MJ
1993 Suns   1634    MJ
It's a team sport!
Would LeBron have gone 6-0 against the teams Jordan faced?
Would Jordan have gone 3-6 against the teams LeBron faced?
It's impossible to know.
But in looking how each team stacked up to their respective opponents, we can get a sense for whether or not both won the right number of rings. 
ELO Rating in Finals
    Jordan  LeBron
Team rating 1770    1687
Opponent    1706    1750
Difference  +64 -63
On average, Jordan's teams entered the Finals with an ELO rating of 64 points higher than their opponents. That's about the difference this season between the Lakers and Mavericks.
If you take those Bulls teams and instead compare them to the average opponent faced by LeBron James, they would have entered the Finals with an ELO rating of just 20 points higher. That's about the difference this season between the Lakers and Bucks.
What if we do the same for LeBron?
Coincidentally, his teams on average entered with an ELO rating 63 points worse than his opponents. Even if you throw out the Warriors teams and only look at the other series, his teams on average had an ELO rating 32 points worse than their opponents.
In five of his six appearances in the Finals, Jordan entered with the better team. The exception? 1998, when the Bulls (1761) and Jazz (1762) entered with almost identical ELO ratings in what was essentially a coin flip.
MJ and LeBron in Finals
Infogram
What does all of this mean?
In short, it doesn't change anything.
But it should at least frame how we think about 6-0 and 3-6 when it comes to debating the individual merits of MJ and LeBron.
Jordan probably wouldn't have gone 6-0 against the same level of competition that James faced in the NBA Finals.
Conversely, James probably goes better than 3-6 had he been fortunate enough to face teams like the ones that Jordan saw over the course of his run through the 90s.
The views expressed here to not represent those of the NBA or its clubs.
MICAH ADAMS
Micah Adams is a Managing Editor and Head of Affiliate and Commercial Content at Sporting News. Prior to joining SN in 2021, Adams spent over a decade producing and leading content teams at ESPN, DAZN and The Social Institute. Adams graduated from Duke University in 2009 and remains a Cameron Crazie at heart well into his 30s. When not losing sleep or hair over the Blue Devils, Kansas City Chiefs, Chicago Bulls, and USMNT, Adams enjoys chasing his two small children around along with his wife, losing golf balls, spending time outdoors and binging terrible movies.

All of LeBron James’ NBA Records
From 2003 to today, he has amassed an incredible number of achievements

Team Dunkest 2024-12-20T11:30:00
Share:     

Here are all of LeBron James’ records in the NBA. In his 21-year career, LeBron James has never shown signs of slowing down. Looking at his recent seasons, it almost seems like he has just reached his peak.
LeBron James entered the NBA as the first overall pick in the 2003 Draft, and from there, he became a four-time MVP and a perennial All-Star, ranking second in both All-Star selections and games played. He is the first player in NBA history to reach 30,000 points, 10,000 rebounds, and 10,000 assists—a record that will likely remain unbeaten for decades. Moreover, on February 8, 2023, he became the all-time leading scorer, surpassing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.
The debate over the greatest of all time has never been as heated as it has been since 2012, the year of his first NBA championship. Since then, LeBron James has climbed the pyramid, surpassing other legends such as Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, Bill Russell, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, and Wilt Chamberlain.
Today, we present to you all of LeBron James’ statistics for the Regular Season and Playoffs, indicating his position in the all-time rankings for each category.
Considering LeBron’s desire to play alongside his two sons, Bronny and Bryce, what other records will “The Chosen One” be able to break?

LeBron James Records
His resume is so full of accolades and broken records that we could fill a 200-page book. With the advanced statistics mentioned earlier, we have only touched on a portion of his achievements.
A special mention goes to the record LeBron James achieved in the game against the Phoenix Suns on March 14th. The Akron native became the first player in NBA history to reach the milestone of 30,000 points, 10,000 rebounds, and 10,000 assists, numbers never seen before. And it seems that, despite being 39 years old, “The Chosen One” doesn’t want to stop there!
If you want to delve further, you can find a complete list of all his records on this Wikipedia page.

The New Scoring King


LeBron James and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar are the two most prolific scorers in NBA history thanks to a combination of production and longevity over two decades in the league.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and LeBron James are the only two players to ever reach 38,000 career points. Can you guess the scoring progressions throughout their careers?


An elite scorer from Day 1, Kareem averaged 28.8 points as a rookie in 1969-70. He scored 14,211 points in six seasons in Milwaukee, then headed to L.A. He reached the top 10 in 1977, passed Wilt Chamberlain to become the all-time leader in 1984 and retired in 1989.

Entering the NBA in 2003 out of high school, LeBron began his journey up the scoring ranks at a similar pace to Kareem. LeBron’s the youngest player to reach 10K, 20K and 30K career points and has averaged 25+ points for 19 straight seasons.


Entering the 2022-23 season, it was not a question of if – but rather when – LeBron would break Kareem’s all-time scoring record.

LeBron’s Evolution As A Scorer


LeBron’s path to the all-time scoring title has included over 14K baskets, 2K 3-pointers, and 8K free throws. Looking at shot charts from his rookie season until now will show how his shot selection has changed over the past 20 seasons.

As a rookie, LeBron averaged 20.9 PPG. He was, as always, effective in the paint, but shot a career-low 29.0% from 3-point range.

In 2012-13 with Miami, LeBron remained dominant in the paint, but also had his most efficient season from deep — shooting 40.6% from 3-point range – providing a preview to next evolution of his scoring.

In his last two seasons with the Lakers, you can see how LeBron’s scoring has evolved, shifting more towards the perimeter. This transformation has ensured LeBron’s prolonged greatness.


Which teams did LeBron score the most against?


LeBron’s tortured many fan bases across the NBA over the past 20 seasons. From his career-best 61-point game against Charlotte, to his multiple 50+ point games against Washington, New York and Milwaukee, here’s a look at which teams he’s scored the most points against.

No team has allowed more points to LeBron James than the Milwaukee Bucks. LeBron has scored 1,749 points in 61 career games vs. Milwaukee for an average of 28.7 PPG.

During his 11 seasons in Cleveland, over two stints, LeBron scored more points against the Chicago Bulls (1,217) than any other opponent.

During his four-year run with the Heat from 2010-2014, LeBron scored more points against the Charlotte Bobcats (Charlotte Hornets franchise) than any other opponent.

Since joining the Lakers in 2018, LeBron has scored more points against the San Antonio Spurs (409) than any other opponent.

Here is another look at LeBron’s scoring against all opponents

Here’s the breakdown with the Cavaliers

Here’s the breakdown with the Heat

Here’s the breakdown with the Lakers

Assisting The King


Of LeBron’s 14,040 field goals made, 5,220 have been assisted by a teammate entering Tuesday night. Which players have set up LeBron to score most frequently during his time in Cleveland, Miami and Los Angeles?

LeBron and Dwyane Wade spent four seasons together in Miami and half a season as teammates in Cleveland. During that time, Wade assisted on 361 of LeBron’s made baskets, the most of any teammate. The partnership was reciprocal as LeBron assisted Wade 428 times.

Over LeBron’s 11 seasons in Cleveland, no player set up scoring opportunities for LeBron more than Eric Snow with 292 assists.

Of Dwyane Wade’s 361 assists to LeBron, 337 came during their four years as teammates in Miami. Mario Chalmers ranked second with 271 assists to LeBron with the Heat.

This is the second season that LeBron and Russell Westbrook have been teammates with Russ dishing 168 assists to LeBron, the most of any Laker during LeBron’s four-plus seasons in L.A.

Here are the players that assisted LeBron grouped together by team. Click the play button or use the scroll to see his top connections season by season.


Here is a look at the top players that assisted LeBron throughout his career. Use the dropdown to sort by season.


LeBron’s Go-To Scoring Moves


While Kareem dominated opponents with his signature Skyhook, LeBron’s scoring has come from all over the court on a variety of shot types: from thunderous dunks to fadeaway jumpers.

He even took a few hook shots of his own.

Jump shots have been a staple of LeBron’s scoring, accounting for at least 30% of his offense in all but one season.

This season, layups have surpassed jumpers as the biggest slice of his scoring pie, which can be seen here, and split between home and road games.

A year-by-year breakdown of every shot type from LeBron by total points scored.

A Three-Level Scorer


When LeBron passes Kareem in scoring, he’ll do so while making nearly 1,800 fewer baskets. LeBron makes up the gap with an additional 1,300+ free throws and over 2,200 3-pointers (compared to Kareem’s 1).

Track how LeBron’s scoring on 2s, 3s and free throws has evolved over the course of his career.

A season-by-season look at LeBron’s scoring splits between free throws, 2-pointers and 3-pointers based on percentage of total points. LeBron’s percentage of points on 3-pointers went from 11% in his rookie season to 28% last season in L.A.

A season-by-season look at LeBron’s scoring splits, using total points scored rather than percentages. LeBron (2,478 points in 2005-06) and Kareem (2,822 points in 1971-72) both posted their highest single-season points total in their third season.

LeBron’s scoring splits divided by team, looking at percentage of points scored.

LeBron’s scoring splits divided by team, looking at total points scored.

artifact_ids.query: Jordan's Finals opponents strength vs. LeBron's Finals opponents strength comparison

results.title: Complete comparison between LeBron James, Michael Jordan's Finals opponents
results.content: Another user Naabahs, commented on the thread, this time comparing LeBron and Jordan's opponents via SRS or Simple Rating System.The metric is rating that takes into account average point differential and strength of schedule. The user concluded that the average SRS for Jordan Finals opponents is 6.84, while the average SRS for LeBron Finals opponents is 8.20.
results.raw_content:
Complete comparison between LeBron James, Michael Jordan’s Finals opponents

Virgil Villanueva

Since winning multiple rings, LeBron James has crept his way into comparisons with Michael Jordan, the guy considered the best player of all time. Jordan reached the NBA Finals six times and won every one. James, meanwhile, has made it to eight times, including seven consecutive appearances, winning three titles.

But for Reddit user claimsman11, the aforementioned numbers are not enough. He posted a complete comparison between LeBron and Jordan’s opponents in the NBA Finals.

Considering all of Jordan’s opponents in the Finals, the offensive rating of those combined teams averaged out to fourth in the NBA and an defensive rating that averaged out to 7.5th in the league. LeBron’s foes, meanwhile, have an offensive rating that averaged out to 4.1 and a defensive rating that averaged out to 4.4.

By individual accolades, Jordan has gone up against five All-NBA 1st team members, two All-NBA 2nd, two All-NBA 3rd, three All-NBA Defense 1st team, and three All-NBA Defense 2nd tea.

LeBron has gone up against five All-NBA 1st team members, seven All-NBA 2nd, three All-NBA 3rd, six All-NBA Defense 1st team, and three All-NBA Defense 2nd team.

Both of them have gone up against two MVPs.

Another user Naabahs, commented on the thread, this time comparing LeBron and Jordan’s opponents via SRS or Simple Rating System. The metric is rating that takes into account average point differential and strength of schedule.

The user concluded that the average SRS for Jordan Finals opponents is 6.84, while the average SRS for LeBron Finals opponents is 8.20.

Apparently, the number of titles one has is not enough in determining who’s the greatest in the game. It is also determined by era and the rating of the teams they have played against.

If you line up all 18 of their Conference Finals opponents, four of the top five were foes of Jordan's Bulls while seven of the bottom eight teams were ones that faced off against LeBron's Cavs or Heat. On average, Jordan's teams entered the Finals with an ELO rating of 64 points higher than their opponents. If you take those Bulls teams and instead compare them to the average opponent faced by LeBron James, they would have entered the Finals with an ELO rating of just 20 points higher.

The Last Dance: Did Michael Jordan or LeBron James face tougher competition in the playoffs?
MICAH ADAMS
•
The final two episodes of "The Last Dance" air this weekend and will feature a look back at Michael Jordan's triumph over the Utah Jazz in the 1998 Finals.
When we took a closer look into all 37 of Jordan's playoff opponents, we found that the 1998 Jazz team was not only the best team that those Bulls faced off against in the NBA Finals, but also the best team that Jordan ever beat in the playoffs. That's according to FiveThirtyEight's Complete History of the NBA which includes power ratings for every team after every single game in NBA history.
MORE: Ranking all 37 of Jordan's playoff opponents
Of course, these days nary a second goes by after uttering Jordan's name before the words "LeBron James" crashes the party.
The GOAT debate between the two legends has raged on for years and recently re-surfaced with the 10-episode arc chronicling Jordan's rise to power throughout the 1990s. As if that fire needed more fuel, ESPN released its updated list of top players of all-time earlier this week with Jordan claiming the top spot just ahead of James.
Honestly, it's a debate that has no right or wrong answer so we're not going to bother getting into it right now.
What we are here to do, however, is shed some light on the teams both legends beat en route to their place atop the NBA's Mt. Rushmore. In poring through all of Jordan's playoff opponents, I couldn't help but wonder how his road to six championships compares with LeBron's. While King James can't match Jordan's ring total, he holds a 9-6 edge in Finals appearances which shoud count for something. 
Is LeBron's count of Finals appearances inflated due to a weakened Eastern Conference? Or does his playoff record stack up favourably to Jordan?
For the purposes of this discussion, we're once again utilizing FiveThirtyEight's all-time team ratings. Curious about how it works? Read more about it here. Rather than bore you with the method beyond the madness, let's dive headfirst into the results sure to drive many mad.
The overall picture
There were 82 playoff opponents to consider in all — 37 for Jordan, 45 for James.
If you simply take the average rating of every team they played, Jordan comes out on top with the harder slate.
MORE: The 76 players with perfect records against MJ
Case closed then, right? That's it, problem solved... thanks for reading!
Not so fast...
There's far more to it than meets the eye.
LeBron's easier path to the Finals
LeBron James has famously never lost in the 1st Round, a perfect 13-0 record.
He didn't just win, he pummels teams. Prior to the grueling seven-game series against the Pacers in 2018, he had won a ridiculous 21 consecutive games in the opening round, essentially never even sweating an early round exit for nearly a decade. The only two players under the current 16-team playoff format (since 1984) that can hold a candle to his early-round dominance are Derek Fisher and Robert Horry, both of whom went 16-0 in the 1st Round.
Unlike Jordan, LeBron never faced a juggernaut early on.
The toughest opponent Jordan ever faced was the 1985-86 Celtics, one of the greatest teams in NBA history who swept Jordan's Bulls despite a stellar showing by the then second-year guard. In addition to that legendary Celtics team that featured five Hall of Famers, Jordan also squared off against a 59-win Milwaukee Bucks team in 1985 that featured the league's best defence spearheaded by two-time Defensive Player of the Year Sidney Moncrief. According to FiveThirtyEight, that Bucks team was better than 34 of the 36 teams that James has played in all rounds leading up to the NBA Finals.
The toughest opponent James has played in the first round was a 2011-12 Knicks team that fired Mike D'Antoni halfway through the season after an 18-24 start. That team starred Carmelo Anthony, a banged up Amar'e Stoudemire and J.R. Smith.
It's not just the first round either.
If you take every team that Jordan and James faced in the East, you'll find that it's Jordan who faced the stiffer competition in rounds leading up to the Finals.
Eight of the toughest 11 opponents belong to Jordan and if you limit it to just the years in which they reached the Finals, six of the top eight were MJ opponents.
It's even more drastic when looking strictly at who each of them faced in the Conference Finals. If you line up all 18 of their Conference Finals opponents, four of the top five were foes of Jordan's Bulls while seven of the bottom eight teams were ones that faced off against LeBron's Cavs or Heat. 
The 1997-98 Pacers team featured in "The Last Dance" that pushed Jordan to seven games ranks higher than eight of the 10 teams LeBron has played in the Conference Finals. The one feather in LeBron's cap is the 2010-11 Bulls who went 62-20 and featured league MVP Derrick Rose. That Bulls team sports a higher ELO rating than any of the teams that Jordan beat in the East, barely edging out the 1993 Knicks.
Hardest Pre-Finals Opponents
Team    Round   Rating  Who?    Result
1986 Celtics    1st Round   1770    MJ  Lost
1989 Pistons    Conf Finals 1767    MJ  Lost
2008 Celtics    Conf Semis  1700    LeBron  Lost
2011 Bulls  Conf Finals 1698    LeBron  Won
1985 Bucks  1st Round   1697    MJ  Lost
1993 Knicks Conf Finals 1696    MJ  Won
1990 Pistons    Conf Finals 1686    MJ  Lost
1998 Pacers Conf Finals 1680    MJ  Won
2009 Magic  Conf Finals 1680    LeBron  Lost
1987 Celtics    1st Round   1676    MJ  Lost
1996 Magic  Conf Finals 1671    MJ  Won
Did LeBron have it easier prior to reaching the Finals? Yes.
But once there... it's an entirely different story.
Finals opponents
The low-hanging fruit is that Jordan never dealt with anyone quite like the Golden State Warriors, a historic juggernaut that just so happened to come along right smack in the middle of LeBron's stranglehold on the East.
Imagine if Jordan's prime ran parallel to Larry Bird's Celtics or Magic Johnson's Lakers? What if instead of catching the tail end of both, he instead ran into them year after year?
There's this tendency to think "Warriors" first and foremost when thinking about LeBron's trips to the Finals and while those teams certainy reign surpreme, they also in a way underscore the relative strength of his other Finals opponents. Back in 2017 I wrote about how LeBron's worst Finals opponent — the 2006-07 San Antonio Spurs — ranked in the 73rd percentile of Finals teams ever. That was before he took on the Warriors for the fourth straight year. 
All nine of LeBron's Finals opponents rank among the top 36 teams ever to reach the NBA Finals, an astounding statement regarding his quality of opposition. 
Even more illuminating is when you factor in how those compare to the teams Michael Jordan squared off against when ammassing that unassailable 6-0 Finals record.
That Spurs team which grades out as the worst of the nine that James played against ranks higher than four of the six teams the Bulls beat, including all three from the first three-peat.
Every Finals Opponent
Team    Rating  Opponent
2017 Warriors   1850    LeBron
2015 Warriors   1802    LeBron
2016 Warriors   1790    LeBron
1998 Jazz   1762    MJ
1997 Jazz   1751    MJ
2012 Thunder    1737    LeBron
2014 Spurs  1730    LeBron
2011 Mavericks  1717    LeBron
2013 Spurs  1711    LeBron
2018 Warriors   1710    LeBron
2007 Spurs  1705    LeBron
1992 Blazers    1702    MJ
1991 Lakers 1697    MJ
1996 Sonics 1695    MJ
1993 Suns   1634    MJ
It's a team sport!
Would LeBron have gone 6-0 against the teams Jordan faced?
Would Jordan have gone 3-6 against the teams LeBron faced?
It's impossible to know.
But in looking how each team stacked up to their respective opponents, we can get a sense for whether or not both won the right number of rings. 
ELO Rating in Finals
    Jordan  LeBron
Team rating 1770    1687
Opponent    1706    1750
Difference  +64 -63
On average, Jordan's teams entered the Finals with an ELO rating of 64 points higher than their opponents. That's about the difference this season between the Lakers and Mavericks.
If you take those Bulls teams and instead compare them to the average opponent faced by LeBron James, they would have entered the Finals with an ELO rating of just 20 points higher. That's about the difference this season between the Lakers and Bucks.
What if we do the same for LeBron?
Coincidentally, his teams on average entered with an ELO rating 63 points worse than his opponents. Even if you throw out the Warriors teams and only look at the other series, his teams on average had an ELO rating 32 points worse than their opponents.
In five of his six appearances in the Finals, Jordan entered with the better team. The exception? 1998, when the Bulls (1761) and Jazz (1762) entered with almost identical ELO ratings in what was essentially a coin flip.
MJ and LeBron in Finals
Infogram
What does all of this mean?
In short, it doesn't change anything.
But it should at least frame how we think about 6-0 and 3-6 when it comes to debating the individual merits of MJ and LeBron.
Jordan probably wouldn't have gone 6-0 against the same level of competition that James faced in the NBA Finals.
Conversely, James probably goes better than 3-6 had he been fortunate enough to face teams like the ones that Jordan saw over the course of his run through the 90s.
The views expressed here to not represent those of the NBA or its clubs.
MICAH ADAMS
Micah Adams is a Managing Editor and Head of Affiliate and Commercial Content at Sporting News. Prior to joining SN in 2021, Adams spent over a decade producing and leading content teams at ESPN, DAZN and The Social Institute. Adams graduated from Duke University in 2009 and remains a Cameron Crazie at heart well into his 30s. When not losing sleep or hair over the Blue Devils, Kansas City Chiefs, Chicago Bulls, and USMNT, Adams enjoys chasing his two small children around along with his wife, losing golf balls, spending time outdoors and binging terrible movies.

results.raw_content:
Comparing Michael Jordan & LeBron James’s Finals All-Star Opponents

When people ask about the Michael Jordan vs LeBron James debate, one of the pro-Michael Jordan arguments revolves around his 6-0 Finals record.

What the younger generation may not know or remember, is exactly who Michael Jordan faced in the Finals.

This is a side by side comparison of the All-Stars that Michael Jordan has faced vs the All-Stars LeBron James has faced.

Who do you think had tougher Finals competition?

Michael Jordan

1991: Magic Johnson and James Worthy.
1992: Clyde Drexler
1993: Charles Barkley, Dan Majerle.
1996: Gary Payton, Shawn Kemp
1997: John Stockton, Karl Malone,
1998: Karl Malone

LeBron James

2007: Tim Duncan, Tony Parker,
2011: Dirk Nowitzki
2012: Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook
2013: Tim Duncan, Tony Parker
2014: Tony Parker
2015: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson
2016: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, Draymond Green
2017: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, Draymond Green, Kevin Durant.

Whilst it’s clear LeBron had a quite a full plate when it comes to amount of All-Stars, who’s were better? Could you make the argument that while LeBron is currently 3-4 he’s had a tougher run? Or were Michael Jordan’s All-Time OG opponents more of a handful?

results.title: Are LeBron's four NBA titles better than Jordan's six?
results.content: The MJ-LeBron debate centers heavily on their performances on the NBA's biggest stage. For Jordan partisans, the Chicago Bulls ' 6-0 record in Finals series -- with MJ winning MVP each time -- is
results.raw_content:
ESPN

NBA

Are LeBron James' four NBA titles better than Michael Jordan's six?

How does LeBron James' NBA Finals résumé compare to Michael Jordan's?

The MJ-LeBron debate centers heavily on their performances on the NBA's biggest stage. For Jordan partisans, the Chicago Bulls' 6-0 record in Finals series -- with MJ winning MVP each time -- is indisputable proof of his superiority. For James believers, his 10 Finals appearances are emblematic of LeBron's longer record of accomplishment.

Let's take a closer look at how both superstars have performed in the NBA Finals.

What do LeBron's and MJ's overall Finals track records tell us about the choice between them as the greatest of all time?

results.raw_content:
LeBron James Crushes Michael Jordan In Key Stats

The eternal debate over basketball’s greatest of all time frequently narrows down to two luminaries: Michael Jordan and LeBron James.  Jordan, with his six championship rings, epitomized dominance in the ’90s, setting a virtually unparalleled standard.

Meanwhile, LeBron’s unique blend of athleticism and versatility redefines what prolonged excellence looks like in the NBA.  Both icons have built near-impenetrable legacies.

So, if we delve into the numbers—championships, MVPs, and more—who truly claims the record books?

NBA Championships

LeBron’s quartet of championships highlights his exceptional ability to adapt and lead, having clinched titles with the Heat, Cavaliers, and Lakers.  Yet, the lingering narrative of his 4-6 NBA Finals record points to the struggles he faced in securing wins when the stakes were at their highest.

On the flip side, Jordan’s six-for-six in Finals appearances with the Bulls remains the gold standard.  His undefeated Finals record stands as a monument to his peerless capacity to deliver during basketball’s most crucial moments.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 0-1

Finals MVPs

Here, LeBron’s talent for taking center stage during the NBA’s grandest series shines through, with noteworthy performances like his near triple-double series in 2016. Yet, for Jordan, every championship came paired with a Finals MVP—showcasing time and again his ability to outshine all competitors on the brightest stage.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 0-2

Regular Season MVPs

LeBron’s run of MVPs underscores his all-around impact and consistent brilliance, although he frequently found himself snubbed perhaps due to voter fatigue. For Jordan, five MVP accolades marked his reign as the unequivocal king of two Chicago Bulls dynasties, reinforcing his long-held status as the best in the league.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 0-3

Scoring Titles

While LeBron excels as a scorer, his focus on all-around play resulted in just one scoring title. Though, surpassing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to become the all-time leading scorer didn’t require him to lead the league every year. Jordan, however, amassed ten scoring titles, with seven consecutive at his zenith, cementing his status as an unparalleled offensive juggernaut.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 0-4

Assist Titles

Showcasing his playmaking prowess, LeBron led the league in assists in 2020, illustrating his capability to quarterback an entire offense. Jordan’s role rarely required him to serve as the principal facilitator, although he remained adept in creating plays when necessary.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 1-4

All-NBA Selections

LeBron’s 20 selections not only reflect his rarefied skill but also underscore his longevity. Remaining one of the top players over two decades is an unprecedented accomplishment. Meanwhile, Jordan’s 11 honors, achieved in a shorter span, were packed with exceptional dominance, each season testimony to his status as the league’s premier player.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 2-4

All-Star Selections

LeBron’s 21 All-Star appearances further emphasize his enduring relevance and adaptability amidst evolving league dynamics. Jordan’s 14 All-Star nods, though fewer, affirm his perennial impact, with court performances that turned the exhibition into prime-time must-watch events.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 3-4

All-Star Game MVPs

In the spotlight of All-Star weekend, both icons displayed their exceptional skills, each capturing three MVP titles. LeBron dazzled with flair and dominance while remaining a crowd-pleaser. Jordan approached these games with a competitive spirit, famously engaging in a memorable clash with Kobe Bryant in 1998.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 4-5

All-Defensive Team Selections

While LeBron has been formidable defensively during stretches, especially in Miami, his collective accolades don’t rival his offensive feats. Jordan’s defense was relentless, earning him nine First Team selections and reinforcing his all-around excellence.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 4-6

Defensive Player of the Year Awards

Defensive dominance is epitomized by Jordan’s 1988 DPOY award, a year in which he also led the league in scoring. It remains one of the most remarkable dual achievements in NBA history.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 4-7

Rookie of the Year

Both athletes burst onto the scene, immediately transforming their teams. LeBron’s debut season hinted at greatness as he elevated a lackluster Cavaliers squad, while Jordan’s 28.2 points per game as a rookie previewed the prolific scorer he would become.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 5-8

Total Win Shares

In terms of win shares, LeBron’s substantial total illustrates his long-term influence on team success, with his versatile skill set contributing to victory over a prolonged career. Jordan, while behind in total count, boasted immense per-season impact amplified by his legendary playoff performances.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 6-8

Career Player Efficiency Rating (PER)

LeBron’s exceptional PER underscores his comprehensive performance levels across every statistical measure. Yet Jordan’s slight edge in this metric highlights his superior efficiency during fewer seasons, a testament to his unparalleled dominance.

LeBron vs. Jordan: 6-9

NBA Cup Titles

LeBron etched his name once more into the history books by securing the first-ever NBA Cup, adding another facet to his illustrious career.

In the expansive realm of basketball debate, the ledger leans towards Jordan. However, this ongoing discourse reminds us how each titan has left an indelible mark on the game, and, perhaps, greatness can indeed wear different forms.

results.title: LeBron James Vs Michael Jordan: Who Was the Better ... - The SportsRush

James has always been a prime-time defender. His defense peaked during his late Cleveland Cavaliers and Miami Heat days. He made the first All-NBA Defensive Teams from 2009 to 2013.
results.raw_content:
LeBron James Vs Michael Jordan: Who Was the Better Defender Between the Two GOAT Candidates?

Shubham Singh|PublishedJan 30, 2024

Credits- USA TODAY Sports

The NBA community is obsessed with the GOAT debate. Usually, the choice boils down to the two NBA legends, Michael Jordan and LeBron James. Since most fans are generally interested in the two players’ contributions on the offensive end, their extraordinary defensive contributions can be often overlooked. Therefore, one interesting way of looking into the GOAT debate can be by examining Jordan and LeBron’s defensive numbers and accomplishments.

Advertisement

To simplify the arguments, one can deploy the usage of defensive win shares and defensive rating as the predominant stats. Defensive win shares is an advanced stat that requires complex calculations. This thorough indicator takes into account the minutes played by the player and the team, league points per possession, defensive rating, and a bunch of other stats that provide a condensed fraction. Simply speaking, the higher a player’s defensive win shares, the more contributions a player has made defensively to the team.

Conversely, when it comes to defensive rating, a lower number is desirable. The defensive rating is measured by how many points a player allows per 100 possessions. Let us take a look at how LeBron James and Michael Jordan do in these two categories and present an overview of their defensive accolades.

LeBron James

James has always been a prime-time defender. His defense peaked during his late Cleveland Cavaliers and Miami Heat days. He made the first All-NBA Defensive Teams from 2009 to 2013. In fact, in 2008-09, the Cavs Forward finished second to 3x DPOY Dwight Howard in the Defensive Player of the Year voting. While in the 2012-13 season, another Center Marc Gasol nabbed the award from the Heat’s Two-Way phenom as he finished with 18 votes compared to Gasol’s 31. In 2014, LeBron made his last All-NBA defensive team when he was selected to the second team.

In terms of All-Time Defensive Win Shares, James is 11th on the list with 79.88 DWS. His defensive rating is placed at an impressive 104.4, just above his former Lakers teammate Dwight Howard. For his career, the four-time NBA Champion has captured around 1.5 steals per game. His best season was his sophomore season when he clinched 2.2 steals per game.

As a premier shot-blocker, James has notched 0.7 blocks per game, going over 1 block a game four times. His chase-down blocks are revered across generations. His block against Andre Iguodala in Game 7 of the 2016 NBA Finals that denied the Warriors a lead remains one of the most historic ones ever.

Michael Jordan

Michael Jordan is one of the best perimeter defenders to play the game. MJ made 9X All-NBA Defensive Teams and even won the Defensive Player of the Year Award in 1988. In terms of Defensive Win Shares, Jordan is 21st All-Time with 64.13. The Guard had a defensive rating of 102.7. He was the league’s steals leader thrice in his career.

MJ finished his career, notching an impressive 2.3 steals per game and is fourth all-time in the steals-per-game department. The six-time NBA Champion was also an impressive shot-blocker, finishing with 0.8 blocks a game. He blocked more than a shot per game four times in his career.

One of the most iconic blocks for MJ came when he was with the Wizards. The Shooting Guard with massive hands had plucked the ball away from Bulls’ Ron Mercer while he was attempting a layup. It was as if the veteran guard snatched a rebound away from a player attempting the shot.

Conclusion

These comparisons again can’t make an objective argument for which player is a better defender. Even though some might give Jordan the edge, they have different profiles. Jordan was more of an on-ball defender but was equally adept at helping from the weak side. Meanwhile, James is one of the best help defenders while equally threatening in one-on-one situations. Both players have been among the best competitors so it is natural that their defense was top-notch. At any rate, this defensive comparison won’t move the needle in the GOAT debate. The more people talk about it, the muddier the water gets.

About the author

Shubham Singh

Shubham Singh is an NBA Journalist at SportsRush. He found his passion in Writing when he couldn't fulfil his dream of playing professional basketball. Shubham is obsessed with box scores and also loves to keep track of advanced stats and is, particularly, fond of writing CoreSport analytical pieces. In the league, his all time favorites were 80s Bad Boys, Pistons, while Dennis Rodman and his enthralling rebounding made him love the game more. It also made him realize that the game is much more than fancy scoring and playmaking. Shubham is also a huge fan of cricket and loves to watch all forms of women sports.

Why LeBron James is the NBA's GOAT: How legend's stats, accolades compare to Michael Jordan in debate
GILBERT MCGREGOR
•
The term "generational" is often used to describe the world's most talented individuals. The most accurate portrayal of generational talents may very well be the dynamic between LeBron James and Michael Jordan.
Born just over 20 years apart, Jordan and James came within months of overlapping in the NBA. Jordan played his final game in April 2003 and James was selected first overall in the NBA Draft two months later.
For the better part of the last 40 seasons, one of Jordan or James has been the face of the league, rewriting the history books with unprecedented levels of excellence. As a result, the two are often mentioned in the conversation as the greatest players to ever play the game.
Who is the greatest of all time? The Sporting News takes a look at the career stats and accolades of James and Jordan to find an answer to one of sports' age-old debates.
SN's NBA HQ: Live NBA scores | Updated NBA standings | Full NBA schedule
Why LeBron James is the NBA's GOAT
Entering his 22nd season, James has turned in the greatest career in NBA history.
An unprecedented run of longevity has seen James continue to perform at an All-NBA level for the entirety of his career, and he will enter his age 40 season as one of the league's best players. As a result, James is rewriting the NBA's record book with untouchable marks.
After becoming the league's all-time leading scorer in 2023, James became the first player in NBA history to surpass the 40,000 career point mark during the 2023-24 season.
James' 22nd NBA season will tie the record previously set by Vince Carter and he has an outside shot of also playing in the most games in NBA history. James holds the record for most All-NBA selections and All-Star Game selections with 20 and stands to add to that tally in 2024-25.
Perhaps the most impressive aspect of James' career is that he has somehow exceeded unprecedented expectations placed upon him as a teenager. James entered the national spotlight as a 16-year-old and has spent the last 25 years thriving in it.
James' list of accolades is highlighted by four NBA titles and four NBA Finals MVP awards. While some may hold James' 4-6 Finals record against him, it says something that he has led three different franchises to the NBA Finals a total of 10 times, including a run of eight consecutive Finals appearances with the Heat and Cavaliers from 2011 to 2018.
While many other all-time greats bowed out earlier in the postseason, James-led teams have come within at least four wins of an NBA title six times. How could you penalize him for that?
MORE: Lakers expectations for JJ Redick are 'a little bit crazy,' says former coach
As for James' wins, some championships hold more weight than others. After winning back-to-back titles with the Heat in 2012 and 2013, James returned to Cleveland in 2014 and, after coming up short in Year 1, led the Cavs to one of the most impressive championships in NBA history.
The 2016 Cavaliers are the first — and only — NBA team to overcome a 3-1 deficit in the NBA Finals, doing so against a Warriors team that won an NBA-record 73 games in the regular season. James' Herculean efforts in that series allowed his team to make history and end a 52-year playoff drought for the city of Cleveland, adding even more meaning for James, a native of Northeast Ohio.
It's also worth mentioning that his next two Finals losses came to the Warriors, who improved on that 73-win team by replacing Harrison Barnes with Kevin Durant. James has come up short against some of the best teams ever assembled.
That championship win in 2016 was James' magnum opus. Leading the Lakers to a championship in 2020 was yet another title that held extra meaning.
In winning a championship during the NBA bubble in Orlando, James earned a seat at the table of Lakers lore and delivered the city of Los Angeles a title in a year where it had experienced unfathomable loss.
Set aside the longevity, numbers and accolades for a moment, and James' GOAT case is rooted in a simple argument: there is no greater basketball player to have ever played the game. At 6-9 and 250 pounds, James is one of the most physically imposing players, blending his size with one-of-a-kind strength, athleticism and basketball IQ.
His scoring and passing are both generational and at his peak, he is one of the stingiest and most versatile defenders to ever play the game. James checks each box of what a great basketball player does well and for the better part of his career, he did them at an all-time level. It quite literally does not get better than that.
NBA POSITIONAL RANKINGS: PG | SG | SF | PF | C
LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Regular season stats
James' longevity gives him the edge in total statistics but Jordan holds the edge in scoring average. To perfectly illustrate their dynamic, James is the league's all-time scoring leader while Jordan has the highest scoring average in league history.
The following stats are up to date as of Oct. 22, 2024.
Stat    James   Jordan
Games   1,492   1,072
Points  40,474  32,292
Points per game 27.1    30.1
Rebounds    11,185  6,672
Rebounds per game   7.5 6.2
Assists 11,009  5,633
Assists per game    7.4 5.3
Steals  2,275   2,514
Steals per game 1.5 2.3
Blocks  1,111   893
Blocks per game 0.7 0.8
FG% 50.6    49.7
3P% 34.8    32.7
FT% 73.6    83.5
LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Playoff stats
Similar to regular season totals, James has a clear advantage in total playoff stats because of his 17 postseason trips and 10 NBA Finals runs.
Jordan, who played in 108 fewer playoff games, is also the all-time leader in playoff points per game.
The following stats are up to date as of Oct. 22, 2024.
